content: Both House and Senate bills for the National Defense Authorization Act for FY2012 address detainee issues at Guantanamo Bay and counterterrorism measures. H.R. 1540 passed the House, while S. 1253 and S. 1867 were reported out of the Senate Armed Services Committee. The Senate passed S. 1867 on December 1, 2011, with provisions inserted into H.R. 1540. Differences between the House and Senate versions will be discussed in conference. The White House has criticized aspects of both bills and threatened to veto any legislation that limits the President's authorities in intelligence collection and counterterrorism efforts. The Administration opposes military detention mandates, limits on executive discretion in prosecuting terrorists, and constraints on detainee transfers. This report analyzes House and Senate bills on detainee provisions, comparing their approaches to key issues. Both bills aim to confirm or expand detention policies. The provisions aim to confirm or expand the detention authority granted to the President after 9/11. The Authorization for Use of Military Force authorized the President to use force against those involved in the attacks to prevent future terrorism. Many captured individuals are affected by these provisions. In 2004, the Supreme Court recognized the President's authority to detain enemy combatants captured while fighting U.S. forces in Afghanistan, including U.S. citizens, as a necessary incident to the Authorization for Use of Military Force. Many individuals captured during U.S. operations have been placed in preventive detention to prevent them from engaging in hostilities or terrorist activities. Some have been tried by military commission, while others have faced terrorism-related charges in civilian court. The Supreme Court's Hamdi decision in 2004 recognized the President's authority to detain enemy combatants, including U.S. citizens, for the duration of hostilities. In rare cases, individuals suspected of terrorist activities linked to Al Qaeda in the United States have been transferred to military custody as "enemy combatants." This included a U.S. citizen with ties to the Taliban and a legal resident alien who had never been to a combat zone but was accused of being an Al Qaeda "sleeper agent." They were eventually transferred back to civil authorities for trial in federal court, raising questions about the legality of their prior military detention. Controversy persists over the appropriate handling of suspected terrorists in U.S. custody. Some argue that suspected terrorists should be held in military custody and tried before a military commission, while others believe they should be transferred to civilian law enforcement for trial in an Article III court. There are also suggestions that executive discretion should be used to decide the best approach for handling suspected terrorists and belligerents in U.S. custody. Controversy arose over whether he should have remained in military custody abroad or transferred to civilian custody immediately.
